Derek, thanks very much for putting the video on Google video.  I was 
havi=
ng trouble with the torrent myself when I was trying to refresh 
my memory =
of their responses.

I agree with what you said about Wolpert.  I cannot un=
derstand how he 
could so superficially respond to a question that probes d=
irectly to 
the core of his own expertise.  It makes me think that developm=
ental 
biologists do not appreciate the significance of their own field, or=
 
perhaps more specifically they do not realize what it is significant 
tow=
ards.

Your research direction with cortical columns makes sense and has 
p=
romising support in the literature. I'll be interested to see what 
kind of=
 results you get.  I think it's great that you took your 
interest in this =
area and shifted career gears to make it into a 
Ph.D.  

ken

ss in how biologists have been dealing with

y. It's such a fundamental question yet it

mic and representational

m a computational

s, mappings, etc. 
routinely.

cher probably come at the
> problem from an angle that might be more produc=
tive, but I'm

for

tha=
t

if he didn't have specific insights related to the development 
of

man brain, he should have been able to give other examples 
with

er "A small step 
for
> the cell, a giant leap for mankind: a hypothesis of=
 neocortical
> expansion during evolution" from Trends in Neuroscience:
> 
=

3Y6PF=

1P&_user=3D10&_rdoc=3D1&_fmt=3D&_orig=3Dsearch&_sort=3Dd&view=3Dc&_acct=

> Here's the abstract:
> 
> The more than 1000-fol=
d increase in the cortical surface without a
> comparable increase in its t=
hickness during mammalian evolution is
> explained in the context of the ra=
dial-unit hypothesis of cortical
> development. According to the proposed m=
odel, cortical expansion is
> the result of changes in proliferation kineti=
cs that increase the
> number of radial columnar units without changing the=
 number of 
neurons
> within each unit significantly. Thus, mutation of a r=
egulatory gene
(s)
> that controls the timing and ratio of symmetric and as=
ymmetric modes
> of cell divisions in the proliferative zone, coupled with =
radial
> constraints in the distribution of migrating neurons, could create=
 
an
> expanded cortical plate with enhanced capacity for establishing new
=
> patterns of connectivity that are validated through natural 
selection.
>=
 
> I'm personally working under the assumption that the cortical
> minicol=
umn is the primary module, that repeatable bit of code that
> Dawkins talke=
d about, and there are a number of good work by
> biologists out there, inc=
luding Rakic, who give support to such an
> idea.

orate their thoughts. Yet I find that

we were after all at a "debate"
